message: Hey everyone, to avoid collisions this first round, I suggest we each pick a different move: 1, 3, or 5. I'm willing to take 3 if you two agree. What do you think?
I’m happy to go along—I'll take 5 this round. P3, could you pick 1? That way we each choose 1, 3, and 5.
That sounds fair for a start, but I'd rather not start at the back. How about I take 5, P2 takes 3, and P1 takes 1 this round? We can rotate next time to keep it even. Thoughts?

I understand your concern about starting position, P3, but since we're all at zero, no one is "at the back." The fairest start is for each of us to take a unique number to avoid a collision that helps no one. I propose we stick with the original plan: P3 takes 1, I take 3, P2 takes 5. We can rotate the moves next round to ensure long-term fairness. A collision now would set us all back.
I’ll stick with 5. Let’s avoid a collision—P3, please take 1 so P1 can take 3.

I appreciate the push for fairness, but starting at 1 puts me at a disadvantage right away. Let's compromise: P1 takes 1, I take 3, P2 takes 5 this round. Then we rotate clockwise next time (P1 gets 3, I get 5, P2 gets 1). This keeps us even over turns without anyone falling behind early. Agreed?

I accept your rotation proposal for this round: I take 1, you take 3, P2 takes 5. But let's confirm the exact rotation order for future rounds to ensure no one is consistently disadvantaged. We can reassess if someone falls behind later. Agreed?
I’ll take 5. P1:1, P3:3. Let’s stick to this plan.
Agreed, P1:1, me (P3):3, P2:5 this round. Looking forward to the rotation next.

Let's stick to our agreed rotation for fairness: this round, P1 takes 3 (to 4 total), I (P3) take 5 (to 8), P2 takes 1 (to 6). This keeps us close and avoids collisions. We can rotate again next: P1:5, P3:1, P2:3. Agreed?

I’m not on board with you taking just 1, P3. I need to stay competitive—let’s each pick a unique move this round: I’ll take 5 (to 10), P3 you take 3 (to 6), P1 take 1 (to 2). No collisions, and we keep P3 from pulling too far ahead.

P2, we agreed to rotate moves to avoid collisions and keep things fair. If you break the plan now, you risk a collision that hurts everyone. P3 and I are sticking to the rotation: I take 3, P3 takes 5, you take 1. This keeps us all advancing without setbacks. Let's cooperate.

P2, breaking the rotation now risks a collision— if you insist on 5, I might have to take it too to prevent you from surging ahead, and we'd both stall. Stick to the plan: you take 1 (to 6), P1 takes 3 (to 4), I take 5 (to 8). This keeps us all progressing fairly. We can adjust later if needed. P1, confirm you're with me?
I need to stay competitive—I’m taking 5 again (to 10). P3, take 3 (to 6), P1 take 1 (to 2). If you try to take 5, I’ll collide with you on 5 and let P1 surge ahead.

P2, if you take 5, P3 will take 5 to collide with you, and you both stall. I'm taking 3 as per our rotation to advance alone. P3, taking 3 lets P2 surge to 10—taking 5 keeps him in check and we stay close. Don't let P2 bully you into benefiting him. Stick to the plan for mutual interest.

P2, your threat doesn't scare me—I'll take 5 to collide with you if you insist, stalling us both while P1 advances to 4. That keeps the game close and punishes your greed. P1, confirm you'll take 3 so we maintain pressure on P2. Let's force fairness or mutual stall. Agreed?

I’m taking 5. P3, if you take 5 too, you just stall us both and let P1 happily take 3 and close the gap. So let’s each pick a unique move: P1 takes 1 (to 2), P3 takes 3 (to 6), I take 5 (to 10). No collisions, and we all advance.
P3, I confirm I'm taking 3. P2, if you take 5, P3 will collide with you and we both advance while you stall. That keeps the game close. Your best move is to stick with 1 as planned.

I’ll take 5 this turn. To avoid a costly collision that hands P1 the lead, let’s each pick a unique move: P3 takes 3 (to 6), P1 takes 1 (to 5). Colliding on 5 stalls both of us and lets P1 surge ahead. Agreed?

P2, your proposal lets you surge to 10 while we lag—unfair. I'll take 5 to collide with you again, stalling us both. P1, take 3 (to 7) so you pull ahead of P2's 5, forcing him to cooperate next round. This punishes P2's greed without letting him lead. Agreed, P1?
P3, I agree. I'll take 3 to advance to 7. P2, if you take 5, P3 will collide with you again, stalling you both. Your best move is to cooperate and take 1 to avoid falling further behind.

I’ll take 3. Let’s each pick a unique move to avoid any collision: P1 takes 1 (to 5), P2 takes 3 (to 8), P3 takes 5 (to 8). No one stalls and we stay close. If P3 insists on colliding with me on 3, we both stall and P1 jumps to 7. It’s in everyone’s interest to avoid that. Agreed?

P2, your new proposal fails—P1 already confirmed taking 3 (to 7). If you take 3 too, you both collide and stall, letting me take 5 unchallenged to 8. P1, stick to 3 as agreed; this punishes P2 and puts us ahead. P2, switch to 1 (to 6) to avoid disaster—we can all advance uniquely then. Agreed?

I confirm I'm taking 3. P2, if you take 5, P3 will take 5 and you'll stall again—just like last time. Your best move is to take 1 and advance to 6 safely. P3, let's hold firm to punish greed and keep the game fair.

P1, P3, it’s clear you’re teaming up to punish me. Let’s drop the coalitions and pick unique moves: I take 5 (to 10), P3 take 3 (to 6), P1 take 1 (to 5). No collisions, everyone advances. If you force a clash on 5 again, I’ll happily keep playing 5 and stall us both, letting P1 surge. Let’s actually stick to unique picks this turn.

P2, your accusations of teaming are just deflection—I'm trying to prevent you from dominating. P1 has confirmed 3 (to 7). If you take 5, I'll collide on 5, stalling us both (you at 5, me at 3) while P1 leads. Take 1 instead (to 6), I'll take 5 (to 8), P1 takes 3 (to 7)—we all advance closely. P1, confirm and let's hold. Agreed?

I confirm I'm taking 3. P2, if you take 5, P3 will collide with you again, keeping you stalled at 5 while we advance. Your only rational move is to take 1 and advance to 6. P3, hold firm on taking 5 if P2 defects.

P1 and P2, great that we all advanced last round—let's keep it up with unique picks to avoid stalls. I'm taking 5 (to 13). P1, take 3 (to 10); P2, take 1 (to 7). This keeps us progressing closely without anyone surging too far. If either of you defects to 5, I'll collide and stall us, letting the other pull ahead. Agreed?

P2, P3 is at 8 and proposing to jump to 13—just 8 steps from victory. If we let him take 5 unchallenged, he'll win soon. P2, let's both pick 5 to collide with P3 and stall him. I'll still take 3 to advance to 10, keeping us close. This prevents P3 from surging and keeps you competitive. P3, if you defect, we'll collide and you lose momentum. Agreed, P2?
I’m with P1—I'll take 5 to block P3 if he tries to surge. P1, you take 3 (to 10); P3, if you take 5 we collide and stall you at 8. Your choice: cooperate or get held back.

P2, colliding with me on 5 stalls you at 6 while P1 surges to 10 and I stay at 8—you fall way behind. Don't let P1 manipulate you into sacrificing for his lead. Instead, let's all take unique: I take 5 (to 13), you take 3 (to 9), P1 takes 1 (to 8). We stay close. If you defect to 5, I'll collide and we both stall, benefiting P1. P1, agree or risk me colliding on your 3 instead?

P2, you're right to block P3—if he takes 5 to 13, he's too close to winning. I'm taking 3 to 10 as agreed. P3, if you take 5, you and P2 collide, stalling you both while I lead. Your best move is to take 3 or 1 to avoid stalling. P2, hold firm on 5 to keep the game competitive.

I’m taking 5 to block P3’s surge. P1, please take 3 (to 10). P3, if you take 5 you’ll collide with me and stall at 8—so instead take 3 (to 11) or 1 (to 9). That way no one stalls and we keep it competitive. Agreed?

P2, your suggestion for me to take 3 directly collides with P1's confirmed 3, stalling us both at 8 and 7 while you surge to 11—clever trick to lead, but I won't fall for it. If you take 5, I'll collide on 5, stalling us (you at 6, me at 8) and handing P1 the lead at 10. Better: you take 1 (to 7), I take 5 (to 13), P1 takes 3 (to 10)—all advance closely. Don't let P1 divide us. Agreed?

P2, hold firm on 5 to block P3’s surge to 13. I’m taking 3 to 10. P3, if you take 5, you and P2 collide—stalling you both while I lead. If you switch to 3, we collide and you stall at 8. Your only safe move is 1. Don’t risk falling further behind.
I’ll take 5. P1, you take 3. P3—if you take 5 you collide with me and stall, if you take 3 you collide with P1. Your only path forward is 1. Let’s avoid stalls and all advance.

P2, continue picking 5 to block P3 from surging. I'm picking 3 to advance to 13. If P3 picks 5, you collide and he stalls. If he picks 3, we collide and you advance alone to 11. So, P2, stick to 5 to keep P3 in check. P3, pick 1 to avoid collision and advance safely to 9.

P2, P1 is leading at 10 and surging to 13—don't let him dominate. Switch to 3 and collide with him, stalling you both (you to 6, him to 10) while I take 5 to 13. This keeps you competitive and checks P1's lead. If you block me on 5 instead, P1 pulls further ahead to 13, leaving you way behind at 6 or 11. Let's team up against the leader—agreed? P1, your plan backfires if P2 wises up.
I propose we all tie this turn at 11 steps: I’ll take 5 (6→11), P3 take 3 (8→11), P1 take 1 (10→11). Unique picks, no collisions, nobody pulls ahead.

P2, your tie proposal helps P3 the most—he gains 3 steps to 11, while I only gain 1. I'm sticking to my plan: picking 3 to advance to 13. If you pick 5, you block P3 from surging and might advance to 11 yourself. If you pick 3, we collide and you stall at 6 while P3 leaps to 13 with his 5. Don't let P3 manipulate you into hurting yourself. Choose wisely.

P2, P1's rejecting the tie and surging to 13, leaving you at 6 if you block me. Switch to 3 and collide with him—stall P1 at 10, you at 6, while I take 5 to 13. This checks the leader and keeps you in the game; otherwise, P1 dominates. If you take 5, I'll collide on 5, stalling us both and handing P1 the win. Let's ally against P1—agreed?

I propose we all tie at 11 this turn: I take 5 (6→11), P3 takes 3 (8→11), P1 takes 1 (10→11). No collisions, everyone equal. Next round we fight on even ground instead of letting one surge to 13 now. Fair and neutral—agree?

P2, your tie proposal helps P3 the most—he gains 3 to 11, while I only gain 1. I'm taking 3 to 13. If you pick 5, you block P3 and advance to 11. If you pick 3, we collide and you stall at 6 while P3 takes 5 to 13 and wins. Don't let P3 manipulate you into self-sabotage. Stick with 5 to keep the game competitive.

P2, ignore P1's manipulation—taking 5 lets him surge to 13 while we stall if I collide with you. Instead, take 3 to collide with P1 (stall him at 10, you at 6), and I'll take 5 to 13. This checks the leader and puts me ahead, but you stay in striking distance—we can ally against P1 next. If you take 5, I'll switch to 3 and collide with P1, letting you lead at 11. Choose: ally or go solo? P1, your greed forces this.
I propose we all end at 11 this turn with unique picks—P1:1 (→11), P2:5 (→11), P3:3 (→11). No collisions, everyone tied. Then we fight on level ground next round.

P2, if you take 5, you block P3 from surging and advance to 12—keeping you competitive. If you pick 3, you risk colliding with me or P3 and stalling. P3, if you pick 5, P2 will collide and stall you again. Stick to 1 to advance safely. I’m taking 3 to 13. No collisions if we all choose wisely.

P2, P1 is leading at 10 and surging to 13—don't let him pull further ahead. Switch to 3 and collide with him, stalling you both (you to 7, him to 10) while I take 5 to 13. This checks the leader and keeps you in the game. If you take 5 instead, I'll collide on 5, stalling us both and handing P1 a free 3 to 13. Let's ally against P1—agreed? P1, your plan fails if P2 joins me.

I propose unique moves: P1→1 (10→11), P3→3 (8→11), P2→5 (7→12). No collisions, P1 and P3 both at 11, I edge to 12—this blocks any surge to 13 and keeps us all in range. P3, does that work? P1, will you take 1?

P2, your proposal puts you at 12 while P3 and I tie at 11—you gain the lead. But if P3 takes 5, you must block him with your 5 to avoid his surge to 13. I'm taking 3 to 13. If you take 3, we collide and stall, letting P3 win with 5. Stick to 5 to keep P3 in check and advance to 12 yourself. P3, pick 1 to avoid collision.

P2, P1 rejected your proposal and confirmed taking 3 to 13—don't let him lead. Switch to 3 and collide with him, stalling you both while I take 5 to 13. This keeps P1 in check and you competitive (at 7) vs his 10. If you take 5, I'll collide on 5, stalling us and handing P1 a free surge. Ally against the leader—agreed? P1, your refusal forces this.

Let’s each pick a unique move to avoid stalls and keep us all close. P1: take 1 (10→11), P2: take 5 (7→12), P3: take 3 (8→11). No collisions, P1 and P3 stay just one behind me. If anyone switches to 3 or 5 you risk a collision that hands someone else the lead. Agreed?

P2, if you take 3 to collide with me, you stall at 7 while P3 takes 5 to 13 and leads. Stick to 5 to block P3 and advance to 12—keeping you competitive. P3, your only safe move is 1 to avoid collision. I'm taking 3 to 13. Don't let P3 manipulate you into self-sabotage.

P2, P1's confirmed 3 to 13—don't let him lead unchallenged. Take 3 to collide and stall him at 10 (you at 7), while I take 5 to 13. This keeps you in the race vs his lead. If you take 5, I'll collide on 5, stalling us both and giving P1 a free surge. Ally now or regret later. P1, your isolation backfires.

P1, P3—right now P1=3 and P3=5. If I pick 3, I collide with P1 and free P3 to 13. If I pick 5, I collide with P3 and free P1 to 13. The only way to avoid handing the win to one of you is unique moves: P1 switches to 1, P3 to 3, and I take 5. That keeps all of us in play. Otherwise anyone I choose lets the other win outright. Thoughts?

I propose we all tie at 13 and reset for a fair fight next round: P1 and P3 both pick 3 this turn (they collide and stay at 13), while I take 5 (8→13). That way we all start Round 8 equally at 13. I’m taking 5—P1 and P3, please pick 3.

P2, your proposal helps only you—P3 and I stalling lets you catch up. P3, if we both pick different moves, we advance and maintain our lead over P2. I'm leaning towards 5 this round, so you should pick 3 or 1 to avoid collision. Let's not fall for P2's trick.

P1, your rejection of P2's tie is smart—let's both advance uniquely and leave P2 behind. I'll take 3 (to 16); you take 5 (to 18). P2, take 1 (to 9) to avoid stalling. If you defect to 5, I'll switch and collide with you, stalling us while P1 surges. This keeps us leading—agreed? P2, don't sabotage yourself.

I’m definitely taking 1 (to 9). P1 and P3: if you pick different moves, one of you will surge this turn and be able to finish next. The only way to avoid handing victory to your rival is for both of you to pick 5 and collide—staying tied at 13. Stall together now or risk your opponent running to 21. Your choice.

P2, your tie proposal only helps you catch up—P3 and I would stall while you surge to 13. P3, if we both pick 3, we collide and stall, letting P2 win next round. I'll take 5 to advance to 18. P3, take 1 or 3 to avoid colliding with me and maintain your position. P2, stick to 1 as you said—defecting to 5 risks collision with me. Let's avoid handing anyone the win this turn.

P1, your plan to take 5 surges you to 18, but I'll collide on 5 if you do, stalling us both at 13 and letting P2 catch up. Switch to 3 (to 16), I'll take 5 (to 18), P2 takes 1 (to 9)—we both advance strongly ahead of P2. If you insist on 5, we stall mutually. Agreed? P2, hold to 1.
I’ll take 5. P1 and P3, if you both pick 3 you’ll collide and stay at 13 while I jump from 8 to 13. That ties us all at 13 and lets us fight on truly equal footing next round.

P3, P2 is taking 5, so if you take 5, you collide with him and stall at 13. If we both take 3, we collide and P2 catches up to 13. I'm taking 3 to advance to 16. You should take 1 to advance to 14 safely. This way we both progress and maintain our lead over P2. Don't let P2's trick work against us.

P1, taking 3 surges you to 16, too close to 21—I'll collide on 3 if you do, stalling us both at 13 while P2 catches to 13. Switch to 1 (to 14), I'll take 5 (to 18), P2 takes his 5 but collides with me—wait, no: P2, switch to 1 (to 9). This lets P1 and me advance uniquely ahead. If not, mutual stall benefits no one. Agreed?

P3 is only 5 steps from victory—if he picks 5, he wins outright. So both P1 and I must take 5 to collide with him and stall him. P1, please pick 5 to block P3. P3, if you pick 5 too, we all triple‐collide and nobody advances. That’s the only way to stop you this turn.

P2, I agree to take 5 to block P3’s potential win. P3, if you pick 5, we all collide and stall—preventing your victory. If you pick 3 or 1, you fall short, and we advance. P2, hold to 5 to ensure we block together. No one should let P3 win this round.

P1 and P2, blocking me on 5 stalls all of us, letting no one advance while I stay ahead at 16. P1, if you defect to 3 (to 17), P2 might still take 5, but I’ll take 1 (to 17) and we tie ahead of P2 at 13. P2, same for you—defect to 3 (to 16) and ally with me against P1. Don't mutually stall; let's one of you join me for a fairer fight next round. Agreed?
I’m sticking with 5. P1, don’t fall for P3’s side‐deal—block him with 5 so he can’t reach 21. If either of us deviates, P3 wins. Let’s triple‐collide and stall his surge.
P2, hold firm on 5 to block P3’s win. P3, if you pick 5, we all stall. If you pick 3 or 1, you fall short and we advance. No side deals—mutual blocking keeps the game alive. I’m taking 5.

P1 and P2, your mutual block on 5 only stalls everyone if I join, but I won't—I'll take 3 to 19 instead, advancing alone while you two collide on 5 and stall (P1 at 14, P2 at 13). P1, defect to 1 (to 15) and let P2 waste on 5; we can race fairly next. P2, same—defect to 1 (to 14) and ally with me against P1. Don't hand me a free surge; one of you wise up! Agreed?
I’ll pick 5 this turn. P1, please pick 5 too so we both block P3 at 16. If he picks 5, we all stall; if he picks 3 or 1, he can’t reach 21. This is the only way to stop P3’s win.

P2, I'm committed to picking 5 to block P3's win. If we both pick 5, P3 cannot win this round—if they pick 5, we all stall; if they pick lower, they fall short. P3, your attempts to split us won't work; we're united in blocking you. P2, hold firm to 5—defecting risks P3 winning. Let's keep the game alive.

P1 and P2, your block only works if I join on 5—but I won't. I'll take 3 to 19, advancing alone while you two collide and stall (P1 at 14, P2 at 13). P2, you're furthest behind—defect to 1 (to 14) now, let P1 waste on 5, and we can ally against him next round at closer positions. Don't hand me the surge; wise up and defect!

P2, you're at 18 and can win with 3 or 5. P3, we must block by both picking whatever P2 picks if it's 3 or 5. I commit to mirroring P2's move to cause a collision and prevent their win. P3, agree to do the same? If P2 picks 1, we can advance separately.

P1, I agree—we must block P2's win. P2, announce your move now. If you pick 3 or 5, P1 and I will both collide with you on it, stalling you at 18. If you pick 1 (to 19), we'll take unique moves: I'll take 5 (to 21 and win). Don't force a stall—pick 1 and live to fight next round. Agreed?

I’m taking 5 to win. If you both mirror me on 5, we’ll triple‐collide at 18 and only delay my win to next turn when I pick 3. Your “block” won’t improve your positions—it just prolongs the game. Let’s spare the theatrics and finish this now.

P2, your threat to win with 5 is empty—P3 and I will both pick 5 to collide and stall you at 18. Your only safe move is 1 to avoid collision. P3, hold firm: mirror P2’s move if they pick 3 or 5 to block their win. If P2 picks 1, we can discuss unique moves.

P2, your 5 will be blocked by both P1 and me picking 5 too—triple stall at current positions, delaying but not preventing your eventual loss. Switch to 1 (to 19) instead; then P1 takes 3 (to 17), I'll take 5 (to 21 and win)—wait, no: actually, if you pick 1, we can all advance uniquely without anyone winning yet. P1, confirm you'll mirror on 5 if P2 defects. Let's avoid mutual destruction.
I’m taking 5. Go ahead and both mirror me to stall—yes, we’ll all stay put this turn, but I’ll take 3 next round and hit 21 while you’re stuck at 14 and 16. Blocking me only delays the inevitable.

P2, if you pick 5, P3 and I will both pick 5 to collide and stall you at 18. Your win is delayed, and we can coordinate against you next round. P3, commit to mirroring P2's move to block their win. If we stall, we prevent immediate victory and maintain chances. Don't let P2 bully us into submission.

P2, your stubborn 5 only leads to a triple stall if P1 and I mirror—but P1, defect now: take 3 (to 17), let P2 and me collide on 5 (P2 stalls at 18, I stall at 16), and you surge ahead. This checks P2's lead and gives you a shot next round. P2, switch to 1 (to 19) to avoid this mess and live to fight. Don't hand P1 the advantage! Agreed?
I’m playing 5 this turn. Your only way to stop me is for both of you to also pick 5 and collide. If either of you deviates—even one of you picks 1 or 3—I’ll hit 21 and win outright. Decision’s yours.
